0:
```json
{
    "Model_Purpose": {
        "full_description": "The purpose of this model is to understand the impact of elites in the spread of norms as an extension of a previous model. The model is designed to test assumptions of norm diffusion theories in an environment where peer pressure is the only mechanism for punishment-based enforcement of norm adoption. It aims to explore how humanitarian norms that lack associated punishments for non-compliance diffuse across society.",
        "research_questions": [
            "How do networked elites influence the diffusion of non-punishment-enforced norms through an artificial society?",
            "What is the role of peer pressure in the adoption of humanitarian norms?",
            "How do different types of agents, such as elites, advocates, and the general population, interact to influence norm adoption?"
        ],
        "system_boundaries": [
            "The model includes three types of agents: elites, advocates, and the general population.",
            "The simulation environment allows agents to interact one-on-one and assess the norm adoption of those who are near them.",
            "The model does not account for punishment mechanisms beyond peer pressure."
        ],
        "outcome_variables": {
            "percent_elites": "Percentage of population who are elites (influencers)",
            "advocate_weight_e": "Weight advocate exerts on the elite agent’s humanitarianism values",
            "peer_weight_e": "Weight placed on interactions with other elite agents",
            "network_size": "Randomized size of network of ‘followers’ of elites",
            "advocate_weight_g": "Weight the advocate exerts on general agents",
            "elite_weight": "Weight given to a networked elite’s norm adoption",
            "general_weight": "Weight given to a one-on-one interaction with a general agent",
            "peer_weight_g": "Weight given to average humanitarian values of a group of nearby agents",
            "percent_advocates": "Percentage of agent population who are advocates promoting a norm",
            "advocate_zeal": "Homogeneous value given to advocate agents’ humanitarianism values",
            "degrade_percent": "Amount per time step that an agent degrades its humanitarianism values, representing donor/compassion fatigue",
            "mu_activist_state": "Mean humanitarianism value of all general agents",
            "mu_activist_threshold": "Mean threshold value of all general agents beyond which they become active humanitarian actors",
            "Population": "Total population of agents"
        }
    }
}
```

3:
```json
{
  "Model_Purpose": {
    "full_description": "The purpose of this model is to understand the impact of elites in the spread of norms as an extension of a previous model. This model is not yet at a stage where we are prepared to verify and validate the model, so we instead performed diagnostics on the model using the ANTS algorithms to look for anomalies across the parameter space. The diagnostics did not indicate problems with the current prototype model that produce erratic results or unexplained outcomes. Future iterations of the model will look to more robust methods of verification and validation. The current model, founded predominantly on norm diffusion theory, is designed to test assumptions of norm diffusion theories in an environment where peer pressure is the only mechanism for punishment-based enforcement of norm adoption.",
    "research_questions": [
      "How do elites influence the diffusion of social norms of humanitarianism?",
      "What role does peer pressure play in the adoption of norms without punishment?",
      "How does the interaction between different agent types affect norm adoption?"
    ],
    "system_boundaries": [],
    "outcome_variables": {
      "percent_elites": "Percentage of population who are elites (influencers)",
      "advocate_weight_e": "Weight advocate exerts on the elite agent’s humanitarianism values",
      "peer_weight_e": "Weight placed on interactions with other elite agents",
      "network_size": "Randomized size of network of ‘followers’ of elites",
      "advocate_weight_g": "Weight the advocate exerts on general agents",
      "elite_weight": "Weight given to a networked elite’s norm adoption",
      "general_weight": "Weight given to a one-on-one interaction with a general agent",
      "peer_weight_g": "Weight given to average humanitarian values of a group of nearby agents",
      "percent_advocates": "What percentage of agent population are advocates who promote a norm",
      "advocate_zeal": "Homogeneous value given to advocate agents’ humanitarianism values",
      "degrade_percent": "Amount per time step that an agent degrades its humanitarianism values, to represent donor/compassion fatigue"
    }
  }
}
```

6:

{
    "Model_Purpose": {
        "full_description": "The purpose of this model is to understand the impact of elites in the spread of norms as an extension of a previous model (Salimi et al. 2018). This model is not yet at a stage where we are prepared to verify and validate the model, so we instead performed diagnostics on the model using the ANTS algorithms to look for anomalies across the parameter space (Miller 1998). The diagnostics did not indicate problems with the current prototype model that produce erratic results or unexplained outcomes. Future iterations of the model will look to more robust methods of verification and validation. The current model, founded predominantly on norm diffusion theory, is designed to test assumptions of norm diffusion theories in an environment where peer pressure is the only mechanism for punishment-based enforcement of norm adoption.",
        "research_questions": [
            "How do elites influence the diffusion of humanitarian norms?",
            "What role does peer pressure play in norm adoption without punishment?",
            "How does the interaction between advocates, elites, and the general population affect norm diffusion?"
        ],
        "system_boundaries": [
            "The model includes three types of agents: elites, advocates, and general individuals.",
            "The simulation environment is designed to explore norm diffusion without punishment-based enforcement.",
            "The model focuses on the emergence and cascade stages of norm diffusion, excluding the internalization stage."
        ],
        "outcome_variables": {
            "percent_elites": "Percentage of population who are elites (influencers)",
            "advocate_weight_e": "Weight advocate exerts on the elite agent’s humanitarianism values",

9:
```json
{
    "Model_Purpose": {
        "full_description": "The purpose of this model is to understand the impact of elites in the spread of norms as an extension of a previous model. This model is not yet at a stage where we are prepared to verify and validate the model, so we instead performed diagnostics on the model using the ANTS algorithms to look for anomalies across the parameter space. The current model, founded predominantly on norm diffusion theory, is designed to test assumptions of norm diffusion theories in an environment where peer pressure is the only mechanism for punishment-based enforcement of norm adoption.",
        "research_questions": [
            "How do humanitarian norms that lack associated punishments for non-compliance diffuse across society?",
            "What role do elites play in the diffusion of social norms of humanitarianism?",
            "How does peer pressure influence the adoption of norms in the absence of formal sanctions?"
        ],
        "system_boundaries": [
            "The model considers norm advocates who promote a norm of humanitarianism, elites who have wide networks to spread the new norm, and general individuals who evaluate the norm pushed from elites and adopted by their peers."
        ],
        "outcome_variables": {
            "percent_elites": "Percentage of population who are elites (influencers)",
            "advocate_weight_e": "Weight advocate exerts on the elite agent’s humanitarianism values",
            "peer_weight_e": "Weight placed on interactions with other elite agents",
            "network_size": "Randomized size of network of ‘followers’ of elites",
            "advocate_weight_g": "Weight the advocate exerts on general agents",
            "elite_weight": "Weight given to a networked elite’s norm adoption",
            "general_weight": "Weight given to a one-on-one interaction with a general agent",
            "peer_weight_g": "Weight given to average humanitarian values of a group of nearby agents",
            "percent_advocates": "What percentage of agent population are advocates who promote a norm",
            "advocate_zeal": "Homogeneous value given to advocate agents’ humanitarianism values",
            "degrade_percent": "Amount per time step that an agent degrades its humanitarianism values, to represent donor/compassion fatigue"
        }
    }
}
```
